column5: assessment method
A system is assessed yes (y) if it automatically assigns a persistent identifier to a research artefact.
column7: using a DOI namespace by default

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if, in addition to a possible unique identifier local to the system, it also supports the generation of a DOI for a research artefact.
column7: default case with use of DOI or HDL provider (registration)

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it allows the import of idenfiers of the research artefact, external to itself.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides a unique identifier for research artefacts that is dereferenceable to the artefact's location in the system.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it enables search over the metadata of the research artefact.
column7: only metadata is searchable with Apache SOLR

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it enables search over the content of the research artefact.
column7: only metadata is searchable with Apache SOLR

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides advanced search features and, if so, justify by listing the features.
column7: many options for filters and facets are available

column5: A system is assessed as providing language support (y) if its interface is available in more than one language.
column7: supports I18N and comes with build-in language pack

column5: A system is assessed as providing protocols and APIs (y) if it makes available at least one protocol and/or API for access to research artefacts.
A system is assesssed yes (y) if it offers a convenient mechanism to perform a long term preservation beyond a simple database backup.
column7: a note to do it yourself

column5: A system is assed high if the uptime is >= 99,9%, it is assessed medium if the uptime is between 99,9% and 99% and low if it is below 99% .

A system is assessed open, if it makes research artefacts public by default. It is assessed as closed if it is primary designed for closed repositories. It is assessed on-request if it offers an on-request feature.
column7: mostly open, but a user can give restricted acces to a research artefact

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it employs a standardised and established format for providing the metadata.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the provision of data in common and standard file formats.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it assigns a persistent identifier (e.g. a stable URL) to the research artefacts.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it allows to customize, extend and limit the metadata schema/format.
column7: every standard can be extended with custom metadata values

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the creation and publication of semantic links between different metadata and/or research artefacts.

column3: Import and upload of metadata and content
column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the import and upload of metadata and data via multiple means, e.g. a web frontend or a standard API. It is assessed partially (p) if it only supports the provision via a web interface.
column7: many operations are possible with the API

column3: Export and download of metadata and content
column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the export and download of metadata and data via multiple means, e.g. a web frontend or a standard API. It is assessed partially (p) if it only supports the download via a web interface.
A system is assessed yes (y) it it supports the creation and maintenance of a customised submission process, including fine-grain access control and role assignment.
column7: only workflows are supportet but the submission process cannot be customized

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides a built-in mechanism to make the metadata and data in other repositories (running the same system) available.
column7: instance can be used as a metadata harvester portal

column5: A system is assessed high (h) if it provides a highly usable and easy-to-understand mechanism to select a fitting licence for an artefact. It is assessed limited (l), if it at least provides a customizable controlled list of licences.
column7: build-in Creative Commons support (with many specific conditions), which can customized by an administrator

column5: A system is assessed high (h) if it provides an easy-to-understand and human-readable description of the terms of use. It is assessed limited (l), if it at least provides a link to the applied licence.
column7: display a link to further describtions

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it allows to access the actual content in a structured and machine-readable manner, if the data format supports it, for example, if a user can access the content of a CSV via an API.
column7: with external tools (e.g. extensions) is a view of content possible

column5: A system is assessed high (h) if the documentation and support are of high quality and reachability.
column7: rich documentation and big community with massive community support and festivals

column5: A system is assessed according to this metrics based on usability testing carried out.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes mechanisms to notify users through mobile apps, email, or other mechanisms.
column7: notifications on the website or with E-Mail

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a way to customise and manage the publication/deposit workflow.
column7: workflows with curation and researchartefact permissions supported

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes ways to visualise the content of publications or datasets, at least for some formats.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes mechanisms to analyse the data in deposited research artefacts, including basic statistical analysis or more advanced methods.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables the publisher or administrator to change the aspect of pages on the system to reflect institutional affiliation.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes ways for users to create, name, and publish arbitrary sets of research artefacts.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides pages for individual researchers, including at least the research artefacts they have authored/published.
column7: no individual profiles included, but a user site with uploaded research artefacts

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it gives the ability to users to provide simple positive feedback ("like") on research artefacts.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables users to comment on individual research artefacts.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides ways to share research artefacts with other users, on the system or other platforms (e.g. social media).
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables users to follow, and receive updates from, other users, research artefacts, collections, institutions, etc.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes discussion forums for users and/or for communication with/from the administrators.

For a proprietary, closed system, the assessement should be "closed" (c). For an open system, assessement is based on the frequency of activities in the development community (daily/weekly updates: high, monthly/quaterly updates: medium, less: low)
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes an authentication mechanism for users.
column7: variety of authentication mechanisms, like ORCID, OAuth, etc.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a review functionality during submission by data stewards or other permitted organizational users.
column7: roles and groups are available with dedicded permissons

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes a functionality for writing reviews on specific research artefacts.
column7: with private URLs users can review research artefacts

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (s) if it records usage statistics and (a) if it provides advanced research indicators like h-Index or AltMetrics.
Date at which the first available artefact was deposited on the platform.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if the underlying system is open source.
column7: mostly use of libraries and frameworks from the Java environment (Apache)

column5: A system is assessed as having high uptake (h) if it is used by a thousands of active users each month.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes automated backups in a constant time interval.
column7: provided a script but admistrator has to manage it

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a function to get all data about one user.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a function to delete all data about one user.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it allows the user to opt-in, agreeing to single personal data management processes individually.

column3: Portable and secure data exchange format
column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides all personal data in an open standard format (e.g. HTML, TXT, PDF).
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes security tests for personal data.
column7: no information available, and depends more on running infrastructure
